document.masterDocTitle: Description of the larva of Aeshna persephone Donnelly, 1961 (Odonata: Aeshnidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Description of the larva of Aeshna persephone Donnelly, 1961 (Odonata: Aeshnidae)

figureCitation.captionText-0: FIGURES 1 – 6. Aeshna persephone, female exuviae, details of morphology. 1) Head, dorsal view (left antennae broken). 2) Right antenna, lateral view. 3) Mandibles: a and b, ventrointernal view of left and right mandibles, respectively; c and d, dorsointernal view of left and right mandibles, respectively. 4) Hypopharynx, ventral view. 5) Right galeolacinia, ventral view. 6) Prementum: a, dorsal view (right movable hook broken); b, detail of ligula, dorsal view; c, left palp, dorsal view.
figureCitation.captionText-1: FIGURES 7 – 11. Aeshna persephone, details of morphology. 7) Thorax: a, right lateral view; b, detail of right prothoracic apophyses, dorsal view. 8) Dorsal view of abdominal segments 2 – 10 showing the color pattern, lateral spines and caudal appendages. 9) Sternites 9 – 10 showing gonapophyses and paraprocts (right paraproct broken). 10) Caudal appendages: a, male’s anal pyramid, dorsal view; b, female’s right cercus, dorsal view; c, same, lateral view. 11) Lateral spine on segment 8 showing the measurement method. Figs. 7 – 9, 10 b – c from a female exuviae.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material. —Six exuviae ( 2 ɗ + 2 Ψ reared), nine larvae. MEXICO , Estado de México ; Municipality of Tejupilco, road 134 Temascaltepec-Tejupilco, Río Chilero,
N 18 ° 58 ' 58 "
;
W 100 ° 03' 54 "
, elevation 1643 m , pine-oak forest,
19 –IX–2009
, 1 Ψ (emerged
28 –IX– 2009
), R. Novelo leg; deposited at Colección Entomológica del Instituto de Ecología, A.C. ( IEXA ), Xalapa; USA , ARIZONA, Cochise County, Southwest Research Station, 5 mi . W of Portal, 1 larva, VII–1956 , 1 ɗ (“emerged at Gainesville”, no date),
VII– 1958
, M. J. Westfall, Jr. leg.; Cochise County, Scotia Canyon, Huachuca Mountains,
18 –IX–2002
, 1 Ψ exuvia, S.

Upson; Cochise County, Ft. Huachuca, stream, upper Garden Canyon,
2 –VIII–2007
, 1 Ψ exuvia, R. A. Behrstock; Cochise County, stream in Scotia Canyon, Coronado National Forest Road 4759 ,
N 31 26 '
56 "
W 110 24 '
3 ", elevation 1810 m ,
26 –VII–2007
, 4 larvae , K. J. Tennessen; ARIZONA, Coconino County, Oak Creek, Hwy. 89 A, Pine Flat Campground,
25 –VI–2003
, 1 ɗ (emerged
15 –VII– 2003
), 1 Ψ (emerged
18 –VII– 2003
),
4 larvae
, K. J. Tennessen; all U.S. specimens deposited in FSCA .

Head. — Wider than long (
Fig. 1
), with moderately abundant, minute, spiniform setae except on anteclypeus, which is notoriously striated; lateral margins behind compound eyes straight and convergent; occipital margin slightly concave, cephalic lobes rounded with longitudinal rows of spiniform setae. Compound eyes large. Antennae 7 –segmented (
Fig. 2
), the third segment the longest, relative length of antennomeres: 0.40 , 0.40 , 1.0, 0.45 , 0.55 , 0.50 , 0.50 , scape and pedicel dark brown with minute spiniform setae mainly on pedicel, flagellomeres yellowish brown and bare. Labrum granulose with a bare, central, oval area (
Fig. 1
), inferior margin setose, maximum distal width about 3 mm . Mandibles (
Fig. 3
) with formula L 1 2 3 4 0 a (m) b (
Figs. 3
a, c) / R 1 2 3 4 y a (m) b (
Figs. 3
b, d) (
Watson 1956
); both mandibles with a dense brush of short, stout, stiff setae along the ventrointernal border (
Figs. 3
a, b). Ventral pad of hypopharynx subpentangonal (
Fig. 4
), densely setose on anterior and lateral margins. Maxilla: galeolacinia with seven long, robust, incurved teeth (
Fig. 5
), and a row of long, stiff setae; a short, basal, blunt spine at inner margin; palp incurved, ending in a robust spine, with numerous stiff long setae on its external surface. Labium: prementumpostmentum articulation reaching the anterior margin of metacoxae. Prementum (
Fig. 6
a) 1.4 – 1.6 times as long as its widest part, lateral margins more or less straight along basal 0.60 and appearing granular, apical 0.40 convex and serrulate. Ligula moderately prominent (
Fig. 6
a), as long as 0.25 of its width; its distal margin (
Fig. 6
b) covered with abundant piliform setae and two small blunt spines, one on each side of median cleft (best seen in ventral view); medial cleft deep, closed. Apical lobe of palp (
Fig. 6
c) squarely truncate, rounded on external angle, with a stout, blunt end-spine at the internal angle; apical margin bare, internal margin serrate; a group of 14–16 setulae extending medially from near base of movable hook to near articulation of palp. Movable hook long, as long as palp; sharply pointed, with a row of 15–17 small, inwardly directed, stiff setae on basal 0.60 of its dorsal surface (
Fig. 6
c).

Thorax. — Pronotum ( Figs. 1 , 7 a) granulose with a transverse, elongated bare area to each side of midline; pale, with two dark wide bands, one to each side of middle; lateral margins produced in a blunt, conical protuberance with minute spiniform setae, posterior margin sinuate. Proepisterna and proepimera projected laterally forming V-shaped, bluntly tipped apophyses, or “prothoracic apophyses” (
Fig. 7
b); proepimeral apophysis the largest; most of proepisterna yellowish brown, most of proepimera dark brown (
Fig. 7
a). Synthorax with a complex color pattern (
Fig. 7
a). Anterior and posterior wing sheaths parallel (when alive), mostly yellowish brown with a longitudinal, dark brown band along costal margin, the anterior ones scarcely surpassing the posterior margin of abdominal segment 3 , the posterior ones reaching basal 0.70 of segment 4 . Legs yellowish brown, with abundant spiniform setae. Femora and tibiae with alternating dark and pale rings, well defined when alive but hardly visible in exuviae; apexes of all tibiae and ventral surfaces of all tarsi with tridentate, scale-like setae; tarsal claws simple with a pulvilliform empodium.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–6.
Aeshna persephone
, female exuviae, details of morphology. 1) Head, dorsal view (left antennae broken). 2) Right antenna, lateral view. 3) Mandibles: a and b, ventrointernal view of left and right mandibles, respectively; c and d, dorsointernal view of left and right mandibles, respectively. 4) Hypopharynx, ventral view. 5) Right galeolacinia, ventral view. 6) Prementum: a, dorsal view (right movable hook broken); b, detail of ligula, dorsal view; c, left palp, dorsal view.

FIGURES 7–11.
Aeshna persephone
, details of morphology. 7) Thorax: a, right lateral view; b, detail of right prothoracic apophyses, dorsal view. 8) Dorsal view of abdominal segments 2–10 showing the color pattern, lateral spines and caudal appendages. 9) Sternites 9–10 showing gonapophyses and paraprocts (right paraproct broken). 10) Caudal appendages: a, male’s anal pyramid, dorsal view; b, female’s right cercus, dorsal view; c, same, lateral view. 11) Lateral spine on segment 8 showing the measurement method. Figs. 7–9, 10b–c from a female exuviae.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. — Larvae of
Aeshna persephone
were found in open rocky streams running through altered pine-oak forest, in reaches 5–10 m wide, with abundant boulders and riffles. The F-0 larvae were at stream’s edge among roots of riparian herbaceous vegetation near large boulders; water flow was very slow. Several specimens had broken structures, such as one of the antennae, movable hook of palp, S 9 posterolateral spine, and tip of paraproct, indicative of a physically challenging environment.
